column4: Does the company consider all applicable laws and regulations?
column6: Clearly defined responsibility and systematic review process established; keeping track on emerging changes and new requirements/legislation; global/regional regulatory requirements (as well as other relevant information) cascaded into the organization and translated into workable local requirements

column4: Does the site have a documented quality management system?
column6: Documented Food Safety/Quality Policy signed by Senior management; periodic review of quality objectives; all employees have access to the relevant documents; risk based self-assessments performed once per year, e.g. internal audits, Management Reviews;

column4: Is risk- and impact assessment an essential element in case of incidents, deviation and changes?
column6: Process mapping and risk assessment for each process; Cross-functional impact assessment; risk assessment based on systematic tools (5-Why, PDCA approach etc.);

column4: Is there a comprehensive change management process?
column6:
Procedure in place; customers are informed in advance and have to acknowledge or approve important changes prior to their execution related to:
e.g. manufacturing sites; manufacturing processes or equipment; product specification or formulation; raw material origin or raw material quality; logbook for important changes kept and reviewed;

column4: Is each customer complaint managed appropriately to prevent recurrence?
column6: Complaints recorded and investigated to systematically determine the root cause and corrective actions developed to prevent recurrence; tools (e.g. 5-Why, 8D report) established that support the investigation process; timelines set up; CAPA submission to customer;

column4: Are corrections and corrective measures for process deviations, audits observations as well as product failures defined?
column6: Process descriptions established; follow-up on CAPA established; due dates monitored; verification of effectiveness of implemented measures; records available; periodic review and trend analysis of customer complaint received;

column4: Is there an appropriate recall/withdrawal procedure in place?
column6: clear process description named responsibilities; emergency contacts, incl. Phone; emergency contacts at authorities; mock recall performed regularly;
column7: If YES, please state the date of the last mock recall and/or confirm whether there has been any true recalls during the past 12 months;

column4: Is there a crisis management and business continuity plan established for the site in case of an incident endangering deliveries?
column6: Comprehensive risk assessment; Disasters, e.g. fire, earthquake, flooding, storm etc.; Managerial aspects, e.g. change of ownership, manufacturing foot print, business critical vacancies; Legal and other aspects, e.g. changed legislation, strikes, riots and civil commotions, lawsuits; mitigation measures defined; procedure includes communication guidelines; up-to-date contact information for key employees and their defined responsibilities;
column7: If YES, please elaborate on the risks that have been considered

column4: Is there a documented supplier qualification system?
column6: Risk based approach, considering the inherent raw material risks as well as supply/performance history; all suppliers have to pass the approval process and evidence available; approach includes supplier audits; suppliers qualified against (globally/intra-company) harmonized standards;

column4: Have all material handling/production steps been subject to a comprehensive HACCP study?
column6: Concept complying with the 7 HACCP principles;  significant biological, physical, chemical food safety hazards and allergens assessed; annual review plus immediate updates upon changes to manufacturing process, equipment or similar; flow chart, incl. verification steps, available and no manufacturing steps omitted; alternative approaches such as FMEA are acceptable as long as risk are systematically assessed;
column7: Please attach the HACCP plan to identify the hazards requiring a CCP/preventive control

column4: Have allergens been included as part of the HACCP plan?
column6: Allergen management program in place; Allergens are included and preventive measure/controls are in place; Clear segregation; risk mitigation measures; proper job order planning considering allergen risks; awareness about crop-rotation and potential mix-ups with non-allergenic produce;

column4: Are CCP/preventive control monitoring measures established for hazards requiring preventive controls?
column6: Critical limits defined per CCP/preventive control/OPRP for each identified hazard; validation of CCP and the critical limits done; verification of CCP, recording and action criteria defined, in case of CCP failure; review of records done regularly at adequate frequencies;
column7: Please list those hazards requiring a CCP/preventive control where a preventive control HAS NOT been applied.  Please attach documentation showing Givaudan has been made aware of this.

column4: Is there a safety sieve or filter in place right before packing/filling?
column6: Max. particle size of 2.0mm (mesh 10); typically defined as CCP/oPRP; checked regularly on presence and integrity of filter/sieve; verification records available;
column7: Please describe the mesh size/filter pore size of sieve/filter as well as the material it is made of

column4: Is there a metal detection and/or removal (magnet) system in place?
column6: In place, regularly tested and calibrated; evidence available; considering ferrous, non-ferrous and stainless steel specimen; verification records available;
column7: Please describe the verified metal detector limits and strength of magnet (if applicable)

column4: Is the production conducted according to fully documented working procedures and/or controlled recipes?
column6: Work orders at point of use; recipes and procedures available for operators (paper or electronically); documents get reviewed/updated if required;

column4: Does the established production process support a fail-safe manufacturing?
column6: Process, personnel and material flows appropriately designed in order to prevent mix-ups, cross-contamination and omission of process steps; all materials and process steps clearly identified throughout the production process;

column4: Are all relevant process parameters recorded and controlled?
column6: Process parameters, e.g. temperature, time, pressure etc., which are critical to product quality and -safety, monitored, controlled and recorded at an appropriate frequency; validation of manufacturing process, considering critical parameters done;

column4: Are rework and reprocessing activities clearly described in corresponding procedures?
column6: Process description and responsibilities defined; process validation to prove suitability for the intended use; customer to be informed about reworked products;

column4: Are records of each manufacturing step kept?
column6: Records in place and correctly filled-in by operators; documented line clearance before start; retention period longer than shelf-life of finished product, with a minimum of 3 years or in line with local regulations;
column7: If YES, please describe minimum retention period

column4: Is there a system in place that allows full traceability throughout the manufacturing process?
column6: Considering used raw materials/ingredients, intermediates, (primary) packaging material and finished products; also indicating manufacturing lines and test equipment used;

column4: Is each probe / sensor for manufacturing equipment appropriate for its intended function?
column6: Accuracy and precision fit for purpose; calibration available; equipment in good condition; redundant equipment for process critical parameters;

column4: Is there a weighing/filling control program in place?
column6: Automated filling process; or manual filling process supported by electronic tools/visualization; recording of filling weight (net, gross, tare);

column4: Is the labelling process controlled and documented?
column6: Precautions to prevent mix up of labels; keeping evidence labels; perform label reconciliation; labels for one batch only available at a time;  no unlabeled receptacles containing product; destruction of unused labels;

column4: Are finished products securely packed?
column6: All individual packages, e.g. drums, bags, boxes etc. for finished products well closed to prevent contamination of finished product; if applicable: protective sheet on pallets, shrink-wrapping etc.; tamper-evidently sealed to reveal unauthorized opening of packaging, containers etc.; usage of desiccant bags clearly marked on the outer package and number of bags traceable/countable;

column4: Is each batch manufactured in a self-contained manner resulting in a unique and homogeneous set of quality parameters?
column6: Quality parameters are homogeneous throughout the batch; blending of sub-batches allowed if each batch on its own complies with the final product specification; full traceability for each sub-batch;

column4: Is there a unique batch code on each delivery of goods?
column6: Unique  code that allows product identification and traceability; clear link to purchase order possible;
column7: Please describe the definition of a batch code:

column4: Is there an internal GMP and hygiene inspection program in place?
column6: Inspection plan in place that covers all relevant areas; responsibility and methods used to verify the effectiveness of the cleaning and sanitation program; predefined frequency, activities and tools to be used; documented drain cleaning procedure;

column4: Is manufacturing equipment checked to be free from contamination prior to its use?
column6: Records for line clearance activities available; visual as well as analytical inspection as far as appropriate; considering caking of product; residues of processed allergenic material, GMO-materials etc.;

column4: Are cleaning activities planned and recorded?
column6: Documented cleaning/sanitation procedures and protocols for equipment as well as production-, warehouse- and laboratory environment; records kept and part of the batch records;

column4: Are cleaning tools managed properly?
column6: Designated storage location for all cleaning tools; segregation of tools per hygiene zone (product contact surfaces, floors etc.); color-coding for cleaning tools; dedicated places for used/dirty and cleaned tools; Tools and other cleaning utensils with allergen contact identified and isolated from non-allergenic ingredients;

column4: Does all processing equipment with direct food contact meet industry sanitary standards or guidelines?
column6: Easy cleanable surfaces; drainable equipment and pipework; materials inert to both processed product and cleaning detergents; where appropriate, equipment made of stainless steel; further hygienic design recommendations by e.g. EHEDG considered;

column4: Is there an insulated spray dryer?
column6: Insulated spray dryer is subject to regular crack testing by a specialist (external) company; test frequency based on equipment risk assessment (age, material quality/thickness, resistance of welding seam, process condition, product types, cleaning process) and likelihood of microbial contamination and its detectability/ monitoring;
column7: Please describe age of spray dryer and date of most recent crack test:

column4: Are there appropriate prerequisites established that guarantee suitability of finished products for the intended use?
column6: Specific requirements, such as Baby Food, individual customer agreements; considering specific contractual requirements; stability protocol in place to justify/confirm expiration periods of finished products; where required to prevent oxidation, stored under nitrogen;

column4: Are allergenic materials handled safely?
column6: Allergen management described; list of all allergens handled on site; allergenic materials labeled as such and kept segregated from non-allergenic materials; precautions established for leakage of allergens; employees aware of potential risks;

column4: Is there an assessment approach available for raw material related risks?
column6: Taking into account, e.g. way of sourcing and manufacturing, cold chain, origination, provenance; appropriate specifications and regulatory documents maintained and updated for purchased materials;

column4: Is there a comprehensive goods receipt procedure established for all raw material and primary packaging materials?
column6: Considering identity, hygienic status, tamper evidence, temperature (if applicable) and labeling of delivered goods; retention samples of raw materials kept; CoA verified upon receipt of raw materials or packaging; cleaning certificates for bulk deliveries in road tank and if applicable dedicated to food use; bulk receiving and transferring equipment (hoses, pumps, filters etc.) must be stored in a secure and sanitary manner;

column4: Are raw materials, intermediates and finished good as well as primary packaging materials and retention samples stored in appropriate conditions?
column6: All materials solely stored inside (incl. protected un-/loading activities); raw materials stored in the correct conditions as detailed in their specification; primary packaging materials kept segregated and covered/protected before use;  FIFO or FEFO principles applied and monitoring of expiry dates; retention samples stored longer than shelf-life;
column7: Please indicate how long retention samples are typically kept

column4: Does all primary packaging materials for finished products comply with the applicable regulations?
column6: Primary packaging is fit for purpose, such as packaging for food ingredients; specification, test reports, migration certificate, food conformity certificate available;

column4: Are laboratory equipment and reference standards well maintained and suitable for the intended use?
column6: Equipment in good condition and well maintained; logbook for each major equipment; reference standards managed regarding shelf-life and appropriate storage condition;

column4: Is laboratory equipment used for release criteria (e.g. scales,  incubators) calibrated at appropriate frequencies?
column6: Calibration done based on protocols and by external (accredited) service provider; internal verification performed with suitable and traceable standards; pre-defined frequencies; out-of-calibration results/ deviations investigated; calibration status clearly visible;

column4: Is there a positive release of purchased raw materials?
column6: Batches are held (in quarantine) until approval by a specifically authorized person (e.g. Quality Control); inspection plan per material; use of cleaned/sanitised sampling tools; number of samples based on statistics and described in sampling procedure/protocol; regular trending of inspection data; reporting on out-of-trend results;

column4: Is there a positive release of finished goods?
column6: Batches are held (in quarantine) until approval by a specifically authorized person (e.g. Quality Control); inspection plan per material; use of cleaned/sanitised sampling tools; number of samples based on statistics and described in sampling procedure/protocol; regular trending of inspection data; reporting on out-of-trend results (e.g. using Statistical Process Control);

column4: Are raw materials and/or finished goods subject to a contaminants monitoring program?
column6: Contaminants monitoring program based on risk assessment and historical data; e.g. pesticides, heavy metals, mycotoxins etc.; clearly defined monitoring frequencies; results/records available; trending of analysis results/data; willingness to share results upon request;

column4: Is there a written procedure dealing with non-conforming (i.e.. out-of-specification) raw materials, intermediates and finished products?
column6: Management of quarantine, rejections, concessions or alternative use, supported by management decision; all rejected materials clearly identified/labeled (physically and/or electronically); investigation reports and corrective action taken for OOS materials;

column4: Have all test methods been documented and formally approved?
column6: Test methods approved and documented in procedures; modified methods and their suitability in comparison to the original methods determined;

column4: Have self-developed methods been validated for the intended use?
column6: Contribution to ring tests or specific verification protocols to demonstrate the method's precision, selectivity, sensitivity and reproducibility;

column4: Are sensory characteristics evaluated as part of a documented testing procedure?
column6: Reference standards used when carrying out sensory evaluations (e.g. paired comparison or triangular test); laboratory properly equipped; separate room / evaluation booth; ventilation system in place; specifically trained lab technicians;

column4: Are microbiological tests carried out in compliance with internationally recognized standards?
column6: Laboratory properly equipped; precaution to prevent spoilage and biohazards; inspections following ISO standards;

column4: Are any of the Quality Control tests carried out by a qualified third party?
column6: All external labs accredited for ISO 17025; certificates in place and all external tests covered by accreditation scope;
column7: If YES, please list the test and laboratories  in the comments

column4: Is there a Certificate of Analysis (CoA) provided for each delivery?
column6: CoA in compliance with customer specification; clear indication with parameters are checked per batch and which ones are  monitoring results; CoA is sent together with the delivery or before receipt of batch;

column4: Are forwarders considered in the preventive action plan to ensure safe deliveries to customers?
column6: Carrier vehicles checked for cleanliness and suitability prior to loading; procedures in place to prevent uncontrolled contamination during transport; agreements not to ship finished goods together with other odor-intensive products; assure appropriate actions/ communication in case of breakdown of vehicle or refrigeration equipment; temperature setting of outbound refrigerated vehicles must be recorded and verified (i.e. use of data logger by forwarder);

column4: Is there an effective segregation between high and low risk operations?
column6: Different hygiene zones, such as dedicated areas for critical activities like sampling, packing, open product handling etc.; specific clothing requirements, such as hair net, beard cover, garments, shoes; air pressure cascade between zones, where appropriate; decisions supported by a risk assessments;
column7: If there are different hygiene zones, please comment

column4: Are there any measures to prevent contamination of the production environment by personnel movements?
column6: Hand sanitation enforced on relevant locations; toilets must not open directly into production, filling or packaging areas; sufficient sanitary areas as well as breakrooms available; smoking, eating,  drinking and taking medicines is forbidden in the production and laboratory area; no use of staples, paper clips or similar in manufacturing areas;

column4: Is there an environmental monitoring program in place?
column6: Swabbing of product contact surfaces and process environment; consider drains; predefined frequencies appropriate for the specific hygiene zone and inherent risk; escalation procedure in case of positive findings in high risk areas, incl. identification of where appropriate;

column4: Are there specific personnel hygiene standards?
column6: Documented requirements and adopted by all personnel, including visitors to the facilities;  jewelry, wearing make-up/cosmetics prohibited (e.g. artificial eyelashes, false fingernails); outdoor clothing and other personal items separately stored from work-wear within changing facilities;

column4: Are there documented and validated cleaning/sanitation procedures?
column6: Procedures, protocols for equipment as well as production-, warehouse- and laboratory environment; records kept; cleaning procedures validated and verified periodically; Check for effectiveness and absence of cleaning residues (e.g. ELISA testing, bioluminescence, micro swabs, final rinse); maximum idle time defined for cleaned, but unused equipment; verification of chemical concentration used for CIP/COP;

column4: Are all cleaning and disinfection agents properly handled?
column6: Approved chemical supplier; list of approved cleaning agents; food grade letters available; cleaning agents labeled and stored in a secure and identified area; clear labeling of both agents and repository; MSDS available for each chemical used; Food grade and non-food grade chemical stored separately;

column4: Is there a formal health and safety program for control of employee illness and communicable diseases?
column6: Depending on local labor laws: employees are not allowed to work with open product in case of open wounds or communicable diseases, if this would pose a risk for the finished goods or the employees; health/ vaccination certificates available;

column4: Are laboratories and their activities segregated appropriately?
column6: Safety of the products is not jeopardized; Test results not influenced by production environment; special precautions for laboratories with microbiological testing (e.g.  Biosafety Cabinet Class II for dealing with pathogens);

column4: Are premises and production equipment inspected regularly and in appropriate condition?
column6: Walls, floors, and ceilings inspected and maintained (e.g. no loose paint, dirt, mold, wood and other contaminants and cracks); equipment well maintained (e.g. no rust, tape engineering, broken parts); exterior grounds well maintained and free from debris, excessive weeds and standing water;

column4: Is there a preventive maintenance program?
column6: Planning of maintenance activities; considering premises and equipment in place; protocols and records for substantial equipment available; only food grade paints and lubricants used for food contact surfaces; if temporary repairs are made, equipment must be controlled to ensure safety of products; special attention paid to CCP monitoring devices; handover procedure after maintenance activities in place; control and reconciliation of maintenance tools used;

column4: Is there an effective pest control program in place?
column6: Considering all relevant/applicable pests, like insects, rodents, birds, spiders, reptiles etc.; operated by external authorized/licensed service provider; contract and insurance available; MSDS available for used pesticides; usage of pesticides recorded; results of pest control inspections both documented and reviewed (service report); follow-up on necessary actions; no toxic substances in production and warehouse environment allowed;

column4: Is the probability of pest infestation or pest ingress minimized?
column6: Preventive measure, e.g. Closed Door policy and fly screens; traps and baits are installed, accessible and fixed in place; pest monitors indicated on a site map; sufficient number of pest monitors inside and outside; use of pest-sighting log;

column4: Is there a glass policy in place?
column6: Register or inventory for glass/brittle materials for regular checks; written procedures for dealing with breakage of glass, ceramics, hard plastic; windows and lamps shatter-proof or shielded in food/food ingredients handling and storage areas; incident reports in place;

column4: Are precautions established to maintain the cold chain?
column6: Temperature and humidity of cold or frozen storage rooms continuously monitored; automatic alert system available; measures in place to prevent undue warming/thawing of product;

column4: Are generator and supply system for process water, ice and steam monitored and maintained?
column6: Process parameters controlled (e.g. temperature, conductivity etc.); maintenance schedule available, considering tanks and loops; sanitation according to planned procedures;

column4: Is there a regular check of process air for material/food processing, equipment cleaning and drying?
column6: Monitoring with regard to microbiological and physical contamination; monitoring based on operating procedures and specifications; air quality compatible with product and process parameters; deviation handling established;

column4: Are generator and supply system for process air monitored and maintained?
column6: Air filters regularly maintained/exchanged according to maintenance schedule; terminal filter before product contact of appropriate filter class (e.g. H10 for cold air, F7 for hot air > 70¡ÆC; according to EHEDG guidelines, EN 779; EN 1822 or equivalent efficiency); filters and oil separators for compressed air;
column7: Please provide details on filters in use:

column4: Is there a regular competency assessment for personnel?
column6: Job descriptions with responsibilities and job requirements for all position; repeated competency assessment for employees and written down e.g. in a skill matrix; skill set described per job positions, in particular for laboratory technicians;

column4: Have appropriate introduction and refresher training programs been established for all positions?
column6: Comprehensive and systematic training program in place for entire staff; reproducible and documented; effectiveness check undertaken for training session to ensure success and meaningfulness of training effort, e.g. by means of tests;

column4: Are employees handling hazardous materials instructed on the label meaning?
column6: Regular training of staff handling of dangerous good and hazardous materials; training participation recorded;

column4: Are employees trained on operating fire extinguishers and  emergency evacuation?
column6: regular training of staff; training participation recorded; regular evacuation drills in place;

column4: Have all relevant employees been trained in Good Manufacturing Practices for cosmetics?
column6: cGMP Cosmetics principles and identification of hazards; allergen handling;

column4: Are personnel and visitors registered?
column6: when entering and leaving the site; valid for entire staff and all visitors;

column4: Are precautions in place that physically prevent unauthorized access/entering to premises and materials?
column6: Site fenced; different buildings with individual access control and access to sensitive areas is limited;

column4: Are precautions in place to detect unauthorized access to premises and materials?
column6: Camera surveillance of the property in operation; controlled/patrolled by guards;

column4: Are computerized systems protected against unauthorized access, manipulation and alteration of both data and records?
column6: Password protection; restricted access to sensitive data; permission granted for relevant data and activities only;

column4: Did the company establish a system to manage environmental protection and occupational health and safety?
column6: EHS Manual available describing EHS policies, guidelines and procedures; named senior management representative or a dedicated department in charge of EHS Management; safety measures included in written and trained operating procedures; site comply with local EHS regulations; monitoring of environmental issues;

column4: Does the company have objectives in place to reduce Green-House-Gas emissions?
column6: Aim to source energy from renewable resources and to minimise the use of energy generated by fossil fuels in order to reduce the company¡¯s impact on climate change; developed an energy conservation program that identifies where energy is used (energy inventory), sets energy reduction goals and regularly measures energy use; GHG reduction targets in place, and aligned with Science Based Targets (consistent with a 1.5¡ÆC pathway);
column7: Please elaborate on the objectives:

column4: Has the company evaluated the impacts of its business activities on biodiversity, especially in protected areas and areas of high conservation value?
column6: Prevent and minimise impact on ecosystems, biodiversity, and the environment of the natural systems from which the company obtains, sources, and produces raw materials;
column7: Examples of biodiversity impact: reduction in number of species, disturbance of wildlife habitats and migration routes, soil quality and soil erosion, water quality and availability

column4: Is there a documented fire-protection concept in place?
column6: Fire fighting equipment (e.g. fire extinguisher, fire hose, sprinkler system) sufficiently available in number, accessible, in working order and appropriate for use;  retention basin for contaminated fire extinguishing water;

column4: Is the company prepared to control emergency situations correctly?
column6: Fire alarm acoustically and optically visible throughout; alarm devices available to detect and engage in cases of fire, spills, gas releases etc.; sufficient number of exits, clearly marked, unblocked and unlocked; evacuation plans visibly posted in local language;

column4: Is handling of hazardous materials, dangerous goods and dangerous processes done under safe and controlled conditions?
column6: E.g. dangerous processes (high pressure processes, exothermic processes) or products (high flammable gas, toxic products, corrosive products etc.); dedicated  and well ventilated premises/storage locations; Material Safety Data Sheets available for all materials and accessible to all employees in the local language; all drums/containers properly labeled with the product name and associated hazards;

column4: Are there measure in place to ensure occupational safety for all employees?
column6: Personal protective equipment (PPE) available according to the type of activity; eye showers and body showers available at each factory/shop floor and in working order; work permits required for activities like welding, working in confined space or other maintenance related work;

column4: Are occupational accidents adequately managed?
column6: Accidents recorded regardless of the severity; first responders/first-aid workers permanently available during regular operation hours; sufficient numbers of first aid kits available, accessible to employees at all times and fully stocked with supplies; medical service available (in-house physician/nurse or hospital close by);
column7: Please elaborate on the number of first responders/first-aid workers:

column4: Is the site in compliance with local emission regulations?
column6: Abiding by regulations for wastewater treatment as well as emissions of polluted air and noise; no dumping of wastes into the environment; if reasonable, wastewater (pre-) treatment (physical, chemical and/or biological) on site;

column4: Has the company evaluated the impacts of its business activities on the availability of water?
column6: Water policy in place, water-related objectives defined and water risk assessment performed; water stewardship programs implemented; considering re-using or recycling water and preventing depletion of water sources;

column4: Has the site identified all waste streams and ensure those are handled in compliance with local laws and regulations?
column6: Ensure that waste (hazardous / non-hazardous) is stored safely in dedicated waste bins, treated appropriately and collected for disposal or recycling by an authorised organisation; prevent mix-up or use of waste materials; making sure that hazardous waste is not irresponsibly handled or discharged; licensed external subcontractor for disposal of waste; objectives in place to reduce waste;  no accumulation of waste attracting pests; closed waste bins;

column4: Does the company have objectives to reduce the use of plastics?
column6: Objectives and planned actions to reduce the use of single-use plastics and/or changing to renewable raw materials in their manufacturing process;

column4: Does the company have a system in place against bribery, corruption and other unethical behaviour?
column6: Policy commitment is the foundation; policy should be approved at a senior level, communicated publicly and reviewed/trained regularly; regular risk assessments and internal audits; grievance/whistleblowing system in place that protects the employees (i.e. anonymous hotline);

column4: Are local labor regulations respected, specifically regarding Child Labor, Forced Labor, Discrimination and Disciplinary Practice?
column6: Copies of regulation readily available to staff; requirements well understood and followed;

column4: Are local labor regulations respected, specifically regarding Freedom of Association, Compensation/Wages and Working Hours available?
column6: Copies of regulation readily available to staff; requirements well understood and followed; working hours are monitored, preventing excessive overtime working;

column4: Is it ensured that there is no child under the legal age employed in the factory?
column6: Child labor is defined as work that is harmful to children i.e., work which is exploitative, prevents children from getting an education or jeopardizes their physical, mental or moral well-being; Suppliers will comply with International Labor Organization (ILO) standards on child labor; No children under the legal age employed at night; in no case lower than 15;
column7: Please mention the legal age in your country

column4: Is it ensured that there is no use of forced labor/prison labor or of human trafficking?
column6: No use of forced labor/prison labor or human trafficking; workers have the freedom of move;

column4: Is it ensured that local regulation regarding legal working hours are respected?
column6: Legal working hours per week are not exceeded; employees have at least one day off per week;
column7: Please mention the local legal working hours per week (or per month) in your country
